title: Polynomials
chapter_overview: This chapter introduces polynomials, their terminology, degree, classification, zeroes, factorisation, and important algebraic identities. It builds the foundation for algebraic manipulation and equation solving in higher classes.
key_definitions: A polynomial p(x) in one variable x is an algebraic expression of the form a_n x^n + a_{n-1} x^{n-1} + ... + a_1 x + a_0, where a_n ≠ 0 and n is a non-negative integer.
Each a_i is called a coefficient, and each term a_i x^i is called a term of the polynomial.
The degree of a polynomial is the highest power of the variable with a non-zero coefficient.
special_cases: The degree of a non-zero constant polynomial is 0.
The degree of the zero polynomial is not defined.
A non-zero constant polynomial has no zero.
Every real number is a zero of the zero polynomial.
zeroes_and_roots: A real number a is called a zero of a polynomial p(x) if p(a) = 0.
Finding a zero of a polynomial is equivalent to solving the equation p(x) = 0.
Every linear polynomial has exactly one zero.
A polynomial of higher degree may have more than one zero.

factor_theorem.statement: x − a is a factor of the polynomial p(x) if and only if p(a) = 0.
use_cases: Factorisation of quadratic and cubic polynomials

skills_gained: Factorising polynomials using identities and the Factor Theorem
Applying algebraic identities to simplify and evaluate expressions
exam_focus_points: Correct use of terminology (linear, quadratic, cubic)
Correct recall and application of algebraic identities
